column1: Some archaeologists' studies suggest the existence of inhabitants in the region now known as Jeddah since the Stone Age seeing as they found some artifacts and 'Thamoudian' writings in Wadi (valley) Breiman east of Jeddah and Wadi Boib northeast of Jeddah. Some historians trace its founding to the tribe of Bani Quda'ah

column3: who considered it a center from which they sailed out into the sea as well as a place for relaxation and well-being. According to some accounts
column4: the history of Jeddah dates back to early times before Alexander the Great
column5: who visited the city between 323 and 356 BC.

column1: In AD 703 Jeddah was briefly occupied by pirates from the Kingdom of Axum. Jeddah has been established as the main city of the historic Hijaz province and a historic port for pilgrims arriving by sea to perform their Hajj pilgrimage in Mecca.
Umayyads inherited the entire Rashidun Caliphate including Hejaz and ruled from 661AD to 750AD. No historic records mention important events taking place in Jeddah during this period of history.

This period was also marked by an Ayyubid process of vigorously strengthening Sunni Muslim dominance in the region by constructing numerous madrasas (Islamic schools) in their major cities. column1: Jeddah is located in Saudi Arabia's Red Sea coastal plain (called Tihamah). Jeddah lies in the Hijazi Tihama (Arabic: تهامة الحجاز) region which is in the lower Hijaz mountains. Historically

column3: Jeddah was a major city of Hejaz Vilayet

column1: Jeddah features an arid climate (BWh) under Koppen's climate classification
column2: with a tropical temperature range. Unlike other Saudi Arabian cities
column3: Jeddah retains its warm temperature in winter
column4: which can range from 15 °C (59 °F) at dawn to 28 °C (82 °F) in the afternoon. Summer temperatures are extremely hot
column5: often breaking the 48 °C (118 °F) mark in the afternoon and dropping to 35 °C (95 °F) in the evening. Summers are also quite steamy
column6: with dew points often exceeding 27 °C (80 °F)
column7: particularly in September. Rainfall in Jeddah is generally sparse
column8: and usually occurs in small amounts in November and December. Heavy thunderstorms are common in winter. The thunderstorm of December 2008 was the largest in recent memory
column9: with rain reaching around 80 mm (3 in). The lowest temperature ever recorded in Jeddah was 9.8 °C (49.6 °F) on February 10
column10: 1993. The highest temperature ever recorded in Jeddah was 52.0 °C (125.6 °F) on June 22
column11: 2010.Dust storms happen in summer and sometimes in winter
column12: coming from the Arabian Peninsula's deserts or from North Africa.

column1: Jeddah is served by King Abdulaziz International Airport. The airport has four passenger terminals. One is the Hajj Terminal

column4: while the Northern Terminal serves foreign airlines. A plan for the extension of the airport is being developed. The Royal Terminal is a special terminal reserved for VIPs
column6: and the Saudi royal family. A portion of the airport
column8: was used by Coalition B-52 heavy bombers during Operation Desert Storm in 1991.

column2: a group of five men associated with the terrorist group Al-Qaeda (Al-Qaeda Organization in the Arabian Peninsula) conducted a mid-day attack on the U.S. Consulate
column3: which killed five Consulate workers. The group was led by Fayez ibn Awwad Al-Jeheni
column4: a former member of Saudi religious police. Two other assailants were subsequently identified by the Saudi authorities as residents of Jeddah's Al-Jamia suburb and other slums on Saudi Arabia's increasingly urbanised west coast. Buildings were attacked
column5: hostages taken and used as human shields
column6: and the U.S. and non-U.S. staff were under siege
column7: although the chancery/consular section building itself was never penetrated. Closed circuit video feeds documented that the Saudi security personnel assigned to protect the facility fled when the vehicle holding the terrorists pulled up to the front gate and ran past the Delta barrier. Inside the compound
column8: however
column9: an armed Saudi security guard employed by the embassy shot and killed one terrorist before being fatally shot himself.

column1: The attackers spread and ignited a flammable liquid on the front of the chancery building
column2: and opened fire on the front doors
column3: both of which actions did not have any penetrating effect. The Consulate's U.S. Marines released tear gas in front of the chancery building
column4: but the terrorists had already left that location. More than an hour later
column5: Saudi special forces made it through traffic and
column6: along with others from their unit who arrived in a helicopter
column7: fought to retake the compound. Two of the terrorists were killed in the final fight
column8: with another dying later in hospital and the final militant being captured alive. Four Saudi special forces and a further 10 hostages were wounded in the crossfire.The five Foreign Service National employees who died during the terrorist attack were Ali Yaslem Bin Talib
column9: Imad e-Deen Musa Ali
column11: Mohammed Baheer Uddin and Jaufar Sadik. The casualties came from Yemen
column14: India and Sri Lanka.The attack underscores the ongoing vulnerabilities of Westerners to threats and terrorist actions in Jeddah and environs. In a communiqué posted in online publications such as Sawt al-Jihad (Voice of Jihad) and Mu'askar al-Battar (Al-Battar Training Camp)
column15: Al-Qaeda hinted at the symbolic nature of the U.S. Consulate attack
column16: stating: "Know that the Mujahideen are determined to continue on their path
column17: and they will not be weakened by what has happened to them."Terrorist activities have persisted from 2004 to the present day. In 2004 there was an unsuccessful shooting attack on a U.S. Marine visiting the Saudi American Bank and an attempt to simultaneously explode car bombs at Saudi American Bank and Saudi British Bank branches in Jeddah on the anniversary of the 2001 "9-11" terrorist attacks on the U.S. On 26 August 2012
column18: a spokesman for the Interior Ministry announced that terrorists were arrested in Jeddah who had been preparing explosives for attacks within the kingdom.

column1: Roads and highways within and exiting the city are frequently clogged with traffic. Mass transit is rare and planning is nascent; most Jeddawi adults have at least one car. Motorcycles are rare on the roads
column2: further impacting the traffic patterns. Days immediately preceding and following the holy days are particularly noisome and cost hundreds of thousands many hours because of traffic jams. The Saudi Gazette reports that there is a plan in the works to tackle the traffic issue. A reported 3 billion Saudi Riyals will be put into constructing flyovers and underpasses in an effort to expedite traffic. The plan is scheduled to take about five years from its start to finish.

column1: Prior to the construction of a waste treatment plant
column2: Jeddah's waste water was disposed of by either discharge into the sea or via absorption into deep underground pits. As the city grew
column3: a proper waste management plant was created and the built up part of the city was connected with a sewer system by the 1970s. However
column4: even with the ever-increasing population
column5: the original sewer system has hardly been expanded. The original plant cannot cope with the amount of waste inundating it daily. As a result
column6: some untreated sewage is discharged directly into the sea and the entire northern part of the city remains completely unconnected to the sewage system
column7: instead relying on septic tanks. This has been responsible for the large number of sewage tankers.

column2: a storm drainage system was built in the south Jeddah area (similar to that of the Los Angeles storm drain) to reduce the risk of floods.
heavy floods affected the city and other areas of Makkah Province. The floods were described by civil defence officials as the worst in 27 years. As of 26 November 2009
column3: 77 people were reported to have been killed
column4: and more than 350 were missing. Some roads were under a metre (three feet) of water on 26 November
column5: and many of the victims were believed to have drowned in their cars. At least 3
column6: 000 vehicles were swept away or damaged. The death toll was expected to rise as flood waters receded
column7: allowing rescuers to reach stranded vehicles.

column3: heavy floods affected the city and other areas of Makkah Province. The cumulative rainfall exceeded the 90 mm (3.5 in) recorded in four hours during the 25 November 2009 flash floods. Streets including Palestine Street
column4: Madinah Road and Wali Al-Ahad Street were either flooded or jammed with traffic. Cars were seen floating in some places. Meanwhile
column5: eyewitnesses told local newspaper Arab News that East Jeddah was swamped and floodwater was rushing west towards the Red Sea
column6: turning streets into rivers once again.

column2: heavy floods affected the city. Streets affected by the flood include Palestine Street
column3: Madinah Road and many others. Cars were seen burning
